Jens Riis Andersenhttp://aarhus-symposium.org/executive-board/ | type = Non-profit organisation | location = [[Aarhus University|University of Aarhus]], [[Aarhus]], [[Denmark]] | website = [http://www.aarhus-symposium.org aarhus-symposium.org] }} '''Aarhus Symposium''' is an annual leadership conference taking place at the [[Aarhus University|University of Aarhus]], [[Denmark]], on the first Friday in November. The aim of the event is to connect leaders of today with leaders of tomorrow. To do so, a wide range of key decision-makers are invited to share their experiences and engage in discussions with students from various universities. Hereby, the symposium allows students to relate their academic insights to the broader business society.http://studerende.au.dk/nyheder-og-arrangementer/nyhedsarkiv/nyhed/artikel/danske-topledere-ruster-au-studerende-til-barsk-virkelighed/ Aarhus Symposium was founded in 2011 and has since expanded its concept to also involve [[Aarhus Symposium#Aarhus Symposium Focus|Aarhus Symposium Focus]]http://www.netvaerksportalen.dk/artikler/studerende-og-topledere-moedes-i-faglig-debat-aarhus-symposium and [[Aarhus Symposium#Aarhus Symposium Challenge|Aarhus Symposium Challenge]].http://borsen.dk/nyheder/avisen/artikel/11/97854/artikel.html Aarhus Symposium is a non-profit organisation, and all symposia are organised by voluntary students together with a pro-bono board of directors.http://jyllands-posten.dk/aarhus/erhverv/ECE7183981/Leder-event-udsolgt-p%C3%A5-90-sekunder/http://aarhus-symposium.org/become-a-partner/ == History == Four students at [[Aarhus University]] established Aarhus Symposium in 2011: David Scherer, Jens Riis Andersen, Kasper Vinther Olesen, and Andreas Emmertsen. They gathered support from other students to organise the very first Aarhus Symposium with the objective of building a bridge between students, i.e. the future leaders, and leaders in today’s businesses and society.http://borsen.dk/nyheder/avisen/artikel/12/3184822/artikel.htmlhttp://stiften.dk/aarhus/Erhvervslivets-tunge-drenge-yder-studiehjaelp/artikel/92572 The first annual Aarhus Symposium welcomed renowned speakers from the business society such as Carsten Bjerg (then CEO of [[Grundfos]]), Lars Rohde (then CEO of [[Arbejdsmarkedets Tillægspension|ATP]]), and Maria Rønn (CEO of [[DR (broadcaster)|Danmarks Radio]]).http://aarhus-symposium.org/past-symposia/growth-in-distressed-economies/ Throughout the years, the programme has extended to include prominent speakers such as [[Frederik, Crown Prince of Denmark|His Royal Highness The Crown Prince of Denmark]],http://kongehuset.dk/menu/nyheder/abning-af-aarhus-symposium-2014 Lars Rebien Sørensen (president and CEO of [[Novo Nordisk]]),http://jyllands-posten.dk/aarhus/ECE8162162/Studerende-har-hyret-verdens-bedste-chef/ and the [[Denmark|Danish]] [[Prime minister|Prime Minister]] [[Lars Løkke Rasmussen]].https://jyskebank.tv/nutidens-og-fremtidens-ledere-modes-til-aarhus Aarhus Symposium has grown through the years as a result of wide support from students, speakers, partners, and others. In 2012, the Organising Committee introduced Battle of the Economists; an event to take place on Monday in the week of Aarhus Symposium. It provided a national focus to the overall theme of Aarhus Symposium.http://borsen.dk/nyheder/avisen/artikel/11/63904/artikel.html The event was renamed Aarhus Symposium Focus in 2016 to broaden the possibilities for topics that exceed economic issues.https://issuu.com/aarhussymposium/docs/booklet2016_final_rgb In 2013, Aarhus Symposium Challenge was established to strengthen the connection between students and the leaders of today. Aarhus Symposium Challenge is an essay competition in which selected speakers put forth a challenge for students to solve. Through their essay, students obtain a seat at both Aarhus Symposium and Aarhus Symposium Focus, and they potentially qualify for [[Aarhus Symposium#Leaders' Forum|Leaders’ Forum]]. Since its initiation in 2013, an increasing number of students have participated in Aarhus Symposium Challenge, making it the primary sign-up for Aarhus Symposium and Aarhus Symposium Focus.http://aarhus-symposium.org/aarhus-symposium-challenge/ == Aarhus Symposium == [[File:ASClimate.jpg|thumb|left|Climate Debate at Aarhus Symposium 2015 between (from left) Andreas Roepstorff, Connie Hedegaard, and Simon Giles moderated by Poul Erik Skammelsen.]] Aarhus Symposium takes place on the first Friday in November. Here, business executives and key decision-makers are invited to share their experiences and insights regarding a specific theme. They do so with different perspectives that reflect the tracks, i.e. subtopics, of the event. {{Clear}} === Past symposia === [[File:ASCrown.jpg|thumb|right|His Royal Highness The Crown Prince of Denmark’s opening speech at Aarhus Symposium 2014.]] {| class="wikitable collapsible" |- ! Christiansen]], CEO, [[The Lego Group]] * Afshan Khan, Regional Director, Europe & Central Asia, [[UNICEF]] * Ulrik Juul Christensen, Executive Chairman, Area9 Group * Rodin Genoff, Founder & Managing Director, Rodin Genoff and Associates * Søren Skou, CEO, [[Maersk Group]] * Jakob Askou Bøss, Senior VP, Corporate Strategy and Stakeholder Relations, [[Ørsted (company)|Ørsted]] * Christian Erfurt, CEO and Co-Founder, Be My Eyes * Michael Bruun, Partner and Managing Director, [[Goldman Sachs]] * Inge Berneke, Partner, [[Egon Zehnder]] * Lars Jannick Johansen, Founder & Managing Partner, The Social Capital Fond * Lene Skole, CEO, Lundbeckfonden |720 |} == Aarhus Symposium Focus == ''Formerly known as Battle of the Economists'' Aarhus Symposium Focus is an annual conference which takes place on Monday in the week of Aarhus Symposium. Here, experts with various backgrounds are invited to share their thoughts on a topic related to the overall theme of Aarhus Symposium. The event provides a national focus as the topic strives to reflect one of Denmark’s most critical challenges.http://borsen.dk/nyheder/opinion/artikel/1/334143/thomas_bernt_loekke-retraete_er_tredobbelt_lussing_til_virksomhederne.html [[File:ASFocus.jpg|thumb|right|Participants at Battle of the Economists 2015]] {| class="wikitable collapsible" |- ! Andersen, professor of economics at [[Aarhus University]] || 400 |- valign="top" ! 2015 | Go Green, Now? || *Ditlev Engel, chairman of the board at Big Future 2025 *Michael Svarer, professor at the Department of Economics and Management, [[Aarhus University]] *Thomas Dalsgaard, executive vice president at [[DONG Energy]] Thermal Power || 450 |- valign="top" ! 2016 | Demographic Changes – How will we work, age, and live? || *Allan Lyngsø Madsen, chief economist at [[Danish Confederation of Trade Unions|LO]] *Torben Tranæs, executive director of Research at SFI *Troels Bjerg, regional CEO Northern Europe at [[ISS A/S]] || 375 |- valign="top" ! 2017 | Globalisation In Reverse – The Danish Response || *[[Christian Friis Bach]], former executive secretary at [United Nations Economic Commission for Europe|UNECE] *Dennis Novy, associate professor of economics at [[University of Warwick]] *Edward Ashbee, associate professor at Department of Business and Politics, [[Copenhagen Business School]] *Thomas Schulz, group CEO at [[FLSmidth]] || 375 |- valign="top" !2018 |Making Automation Work | * Lars Frelle-Petersen, Director of Digisation, Confederation of Danish Industry * Dominik Bösl, Vice President, Consumer Driven Robots, [[KUKA]] * Philipp Schröder, Member of the Danish Disruption Council * David Budtz-Petersen, Head of Research, Humanomics Research Center |400 |} == Aarhus Symposium Challenge == Aarhus Symposium Challenge is an essay competition where selected speakers put forth a challenge for students to solve. Christiansen, CEO, [[The Lego Group]]: ''How a company can enjoy the advantages of collaborating with others wile protecting its core values'' * Afshan Khan, Regional Director Europe & Central Asia, [[UNICEF]]: ''One area in which every child does not have equal opportunities and one way to address this issue'' * Ulrik Juul Christensen, Founder and Executive Chairman, Area9 Group: ''How to achieve a specific competence that will be important on the future labour market'' |} === Leaders' Forum === [[File:ASForum.jpg|thumb|left|Leaders’ Forum session with Connie Hedegaard at Aarhus Symposium 2015.]] Leaders’ Forum is an exclusive and intimate session where selected students discuss their essay contribution with the leader that put forth the respective challenge. Only the best essay contributions under each challenge topic qualifies for this informal session.http://aarhus-symposium.org/challenge-faq/ Throughout the years, Leaders’ Forum has attracted much attention from the media inasmuch as it is unique in a Danish context and provides both the attending students and the top leaders the opportunity to learn from each other.http://borsen.dk/nyheder/avisen/artikel/11/97871/artikel.htmlhttp://www.business.dk/digital/jimmy-maymann-det-nytter-ikke-at-ville-holde-fremskridtet-tilbage {{Clear}} === The Aarhus Symposium Award === [[File:ASAward.jpg|thumb|right|Oskar Harmsen, winner of the Aarhus Symposium Award 2015, rewarded on stage at Aarhus Symposium 2015.]] The most extraordinary essay contribution in Aarhus Symposium Challenge will be rewarded the Aarhus Symposium Award on stage at the very end of Aarhus Symposium. Prior winners of the Aarhus Symposium Award are: *2013: Bastian Stemann Lauhttp://aarhus-symposium.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/08/AarhusSymposiumChallenge2013_WinnerPortrait.pdf *2014: Moma Vujisichttp://aarhus-symposium.org/2014/12/02/meet-the-winner-of-the-aarhus-symposium-award-2014/ *2015: Oskar Harmsenhttp://aarhus-symposium.org/2015/12/18/meet-the-winner-of-the-aarhus-symposium-award-2015/ *2016: Luke McGintyhttp://aarhus-symposium.org/2017/03/26/interview-luke-mcginty-winner-aarhus-symposium-award-2016/ *2017: Bastian Emil Jørgensenhttp://aarhus-symposium.org/2017/11/03/bastian-emil-jorgensen-winner-of-the-aarhus-symposium-award-2017/ *2018: Soraya Redondo Mezmizi {{Clear}} == Other events == Besides facilitating Aarhus Symposium and Aarhus Symposium Focus, Aarhus Symposium also hosts a variety of other events that takes places at Aarhus University. Most notable are Aarhus Symposium Theme Announcement and Aarhus Symposium Challenge Launch; both of which are closely linked to the three key elements of Aarhus Symposium.http://aarhus-symposium.org/news/http://omnibus.au.dk/en/archive/show/artikel/morgendagens-leder-er-det-dig/ == Organising Committee == The Organising Committee of Aarhus Symposium consists of approximately 35 voluntary students,http://aarhus-symposium.org/organisers/ who have the responsibility for planning, funding, promoting, and executing all events.http://bss.au.dk/om-aarhus-bss/nyheder/vis/artikel/hvordan-saetter-man-store-erhvervsledere-i-staevne/ The Organising Committee is divided into smaller groups with specific focus areas:http://aarhus-symposium.org/organisers/the-groups-of-aarhus-symposium/ *Steering Committee *Programme Group *Business Relations Group *Marketing Group *Essentials Group *University Alliances *IT Group *Finance Group == External links == *Website: [http://www.aarhus-symposium.org aarhus-symposium.org] *Aarhus Symposium: [http://www.aarhus-symposium.org/aarhus-symposium aarhus-symposium.org/aarhus-symposium] *Aarhus Symposium Focus: [http://www.aarhus-symposium.org/aarhus-symposium-focus aarhus-symposium.org/aarhus-symposium-focus] *Aarhus Symposium Challenge: [http://www.aarhus-symposium.org/aarhus-symposium-challenge/ aarhus-symposium.org/aarhus-symposium-challenge/] == References == {{reflist|2}} [[Category:Events in Denmark]] [[Category:Organized events]] [[Category:Aarhus University]] [[Category:Student events]] [[Category:Conferences]] [[Category:Academic conferences]] [[Category:Organizations based in Aarhus]] [[Category:Student organizations in Denmark]] [[Category:Non-profit organizations based in Denmark]] [[Category:Business conferences]] [[Category:Autumn events in Denmark]]

{{Infobox person | name =Andrea Elizabeth Michaels | image = Andrea Accepting AwardCropped3.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = Andrea Michaels at the Special Event Convention in 2005. | birth_name = Andrea Elizabeth Gerson | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1943|12|14}} | birth_place = [[Rab]], Croatia | residence = | nationality = | other_names = | ethnicity = | education = | alma_mater = [[University of California at Los Angeles]] | occupation = Event producer, business owner, author and speaker | organization = Extraordinary Events | known_for = | notable_works = | net_worth = | awards = | signature = | signature_alt = | signature_size = | website = {{URL|www.extraordinaryevents.net}} | footnotes = }} '''Andrea Elizabeth Michaels''' (née Gerson; born December 14, 1943) is an American meeting and event producer, author and speaker.<ref name=Stepping>Wright, David, ''Stepping Stones to Success - Experts Share Strategies for Mastering Business, Life and Relationships - with Deepak Chopra, Jack Canfield, Andrea Michaels and Dr. Denis Waitley''. Sevierville, Tennessee: Insight Publishing, 2010, pp. 237-248.</ref> As founder of an international event production company, Extraordinary Events, Michaels and her company produce large corporate events. She is an original member of the special events industry Hall of Fame<ref>Baragona, Carolyn, "Spotlight Award/Hall of Fame Inductees," ''Event Solutions'' magazine, December, 2002.</ref> and the author of a business biography,<ref name=reflect>>Michaels, Andrea, ''Reflections of a Successful Wallflower - Lessons in Business; Lessons in Life.'' Denver: Outskirts Press, 2010.</ref> and is featured in three [[anthologies]].
== Early life == Andrea Michaels was born in the [[Arbe concentration camp]] (today [[Rab]], [[Croatia]], on the northern shore of the [[Adriatic Sea]]) to Lelja Kauders (b. Zagreb, Yugoslavia, August 25, 1923 – d. Los Angeles California, May 30, 2009).<ref>Tributes.com/show/Lelja-Gerson</ref><ref name=ben7879>Wright, David, ''Yes You Can! Reaching Your Potential While Achieving Greatness - with Dr. Warren Bennis, Andrea Michaels and Jim Rohn''. Sevierville, Tennessee: Insight Publishing, 2010, pp. 77-88.</ref> Michaels and her mother, along with her mother's [[Jewish]] parents, Paul (Palvo) Kauders and Elza Ackerman Kauders, escaped in a small boat across the Adriatic to Italy.<ref name="ben7879"/> Michaels lived in Italy to the age of four with her grandparents until her mother, who had married an American pilot, sent for her to come live in America.<ref name="ben7879"/> The marriage ended, and after Michaels arrived in America, her mother married Peter Gerson, who adopted Andrea and moved the family from [[Silverlake, California]], to [[Hollywood]].<ref name="ben7879"/> When Michaels was ten, the family moved to [[Burbank, California]].<ref name="ben7879"/>
An only child Michaels graduated from [[Burbank High School (Burbank, California)|Burbank High School]] in 1961.<ref>http://www.classmates.com/places/school/school/3516/m?startYear=1900&endYear=9999&communityId=3516</ref> Michaels attended the [[University of California at Berkeley]] in 1961 and 1962, transferring to the [[University of California at Los Angeles]] (UCLA) before marrying Bob Spritz on February 1, 1964.<ref name="ben7879"/> The marriage lasted ten years, and they had a son, Jon (b. July 24, 1970).<ref name=reflect/> After her divorce from Spritz, she changed her last name as well as that of her son's to "Michaels."<ref name=reflect/> Michaels returned to UCLA in 1970 and earned a degree, with honors, in [[Psychology]].<ref>2002 Hall of Fame, NAWBOLA.org./About_Us/2002_hof.php</ref>
== Early career == Instead of pursuing a career in Psychology, Michaels began working with the Ron Rubin Orchestras in 1973.<ref>Barnett, Maggie, "Spectacular Events Keep Encino Firm in Demand," Features Section, Los Angeles Times, November 23, 1999.</ref> During that time, she became interested in the [[event planning]] business when there was no formalized industry. She produced her first event in 1978—-a [[Anniversary|bicentennial]] celebration for Marsh McClellan Insurance Company. By 1982, the company had been restructured and renamed Michaels, Rubin and Associates.<ref name=ben7879 /> Michaels and Rubin dissolved their relationship in December 1988, and on that same day, Extraordinary Events was launched.<ref>"Coffee With Andrea Michaels - Meetings And Conventions". Meetings-conventions.com. 2010-08-01. http://www.meetings-conventions.com/articles/coffee-with-andrea-michaels/a35650.aspx. Retrieved 2011-02-09.</ref><ref>Barnett, Maggie, "Spectacular Events Keep Encino Firm in Demand," Features Section, ''Los Angeles Times'', November 23, 1999. Found online as an abstract at [https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/latimes/access/46600664.html?dids=46600664:46600664&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Nov+23%2C+1999&author=MAGGIE+BARNETT&pub=Los+Angeles+Times&desc=VALLEY+BUSINESS+%2F+ADVANCING+WOMEN%3A+PROFILES+OF+SUCCESS%3B+Spectacular+Events+Keep+Encino+Firm+in+Demand%3B+Entertainment%3A+Staging+big+productions+for+major+companies+is+a+hectic+but+profitable+venture+for+one+Valley+entrepreneur.&pqatl=google Los Angeles Times archives]. Accessed March 17, 2011.</ref> At that time, Michaels began to bring to the corporate world the spectaculars that had been produced on football fields, Disneyland and in entertainment venues<ref name=Stepping /> by the late [[Tommy Walker (events director)|Tommy Walker]] and the late [[Robert (Bob) Jani]].
== Later career == Extraordinary Events has specialized in planning and producing corporate events globally including Europe, Asia, Canada, Mexico, the Caribbean, Africa, Australia and New Zealand.<ref name=ben7879 /> In 2006, ''Special Events'' magazine listed Extraordinary Events as one of the "Top 50 Event Planning Companies."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eddiedeensranch.com/press/5th_annual_50_top_event_plan.pdf|title=www.eddiedeensranch.com/press/5th_annual_50_top_event_plan.pdf<!--INSERT TITLE-->|format=PDF}}</ref><ref>Hurley, Lisa, "5th Annual 50 Top Event Planning Companies List," ''Special Events'' magazine, September 12, 2006, pages 45-50.</ref> The [[Los Angeles Business Journal]] named it Number 28 on its list of the "Fastest Growing Private Companies"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.northstarmobilestorage.com/pdf/awards/2006.50_Fastest_Growing_Companies_SFVBJ.pdf|title=www.northstarmobilestorage.com/pdf/awards/2006.50_Fastest_Growing_Companies_SFVBJ.pdf<!--INSERT '''Anthrax hoaxes''' involving the use of white powder or labels to falsely suggest the use of [[anthrax]] are frequently reported in the United States and globally. [[Hoax]]es have increased following the [[2001 anthrax attacks]], after which no genuine anthrax attacks have occurred. The [[FBI]] and [[United States Postal Inspection Service|U.S. postal inspectors]] have responded to thousands of "white powder events" and targets have included government offices, US embassies, banks and news organizations.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2009/mar/08/nation/na-anthrax-threats8|title=Anthrax hoaxes pile up, as does their cost|last=Drogin|first=Bob|date=8 March 2009|work=Los Angeles Times|accessdate=10 December 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Cole|first=Leonard A.|title=The Anthrax Letters: A Bioterrorism Expert Investigates the Attacks That Shocked America--Case Closed?|publisher=Skyhorse Publishing|year=2009|isbn=978-1-60239-715-6|url=http://leonardcole.com}}</ref>
==History== Anthrax hoaxes were sporadically reported in the 1990s,<ref>{{cite book|last=Carus|first=W. Seth|author2=Center for Counterproliferation Research |author3=National Defense University |title=Bioterrorism and biocrimes: the illicit use of biological agents since 1900|publisher=The Minerva Group, Inc.|year=2002|volume=8|chapter=Thrreatened Use (Anthrax Hoaxes)|isbn=1-4101-0023-5|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=1jEP8Ve4zwgC}}</ref> including a petri dish in an envelope labeled "anthrachs"[sic] sent to [[B'nai B'rith]] in Washington in 1997 that contained harmless ''[[Bacillus cereus]]'',<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/25/us/suspicious-package-prompts-8-hour-vigil-at-b-nai-b-rith.html|title=Suspicious Package Prompts 8-Hour Vigil at B'nai B'rith|date=24 April 1997|work=New York Times|accessdate=10 December 2009 | first=Matthew L. | last=Wald}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://reason.com/archives/2001/10/10/anthrax-attack|title=Anthrax Attack?|last=Bailey|first=Ronald|date=10 October 2001|work=Reason|accessdate=10 December 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2002/07/12/opinion/the-anthrax-files.html|title=The Anthrax Files|last=Kristof|first=Nicholas D.|date=12 July 2002|work=New York Times|accessdate=10 December 2009}}</ref> but a spate of anthrax threats followed the 1998 arrest of Larry Wayne Harris, a microbiologist and [[white supremacist]]. Harris released what he said was military-grade anthrax but was actually a harmless vaccine strain, but news coverage popularized the idea of anthrax among hoaxers.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Tucker|first=Jonathan B.|date=July 1999|title=Historical trends related to bioterrorism: An empirical analysis|journal=Emerging Infectious Diseases|publisher=CDC|volume=5|issue=4|url=http://origin.cdc.gov/ncidod/EID/vol5no4/tucker.htm | pmid = 10458952|doi=10.3201/eid0504.990406|pmc=2627752|pages=498–504}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.adl.org/learn/anthrax/Harris.asp?xpicked=3&item=5|title=The Harris Hoax|work=ADL|accessdate=10 December 2009}}</ref> In response to these hoaxes, the [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention|CDC]] released guidance for public health authorities for handling bioterrorism threats.<ref>{{cite journal|year=1999|author1=Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC)|title=Bioterrorism Alleging Use of Anthrax and Interim Guidelines for Management -- United States, 1998|journal=MMWR|publisher=CDC|volume=48|issue=4|pages=69–74|url=https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00056353.htm|pmid=10023627}}</ref>

It was a hoax.]] In the month following the 2001 anthrax attacks, hundreds of hoaxes were reported worldwide.<ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1071/NB03059|last=Leask|first=Alexander|author2=Valerie Delpech |author3=Jeremy McAnulty|title=Anthrax and other suspect powders: Initial responses to an outbreak of hoaxes and scares|journal=New South Wales Public Health Bulletin|publisher=Csiro December 2009}}</ref>
==Cases== One of the most prolific hoaxers was [[Clayton Waagner]], an [[anti-abortion]] activist who mailed hundreds of anthrax hoax letters to abortion clinics in late 2001<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/americas/1695140.stm|title=US anthrax hoax suspect arrested|date=6 December 2001|work=BBC News|accessdate=10 December 2009}}</ref> and who was convicted in December 2003.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/news/nation/2003-12-03-anthrax-hoax_x.htm|title=Man is convicted in anthrax hoax case|work=Associated Press|accessdate=10 December 2009 | date=3 December 2003}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://dir.salon.com/story/news/feature/2003/12/10/waagner/index.html |title=The quiet fall of an American terrorist |last=Clarkson |first=Frederick |date=10 December 2003 |work=Salon |accessdate=10 December 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110320083801/http://dir.salon.com/story/news/feature/2003/12/10/waagner/index.html |archivedate=20 March 2011 |df= }}</ref> A Sacramento man, Marc M. Keyser, admitted to sending around 120 packages marked as containing anthrax in October 2008, which he says was to highlight the lack of preparedness of the [[U.S. Department of Homeland Security]] and public for an anthrax attack. He was convicted in September 2009 of five counts of hoaxes and making threats<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.sacbee.com/ourregion/story/2191521.html|title=Sacramentan convicted for sending anthrax hoax messages|last=Walsh|first=Denny|date=18 September 2009|work=Sacramento Bee|accessdate=10 December 2009}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.salon.com/wires/ap/us/2009/09/17/D9APEMG81_us_anthrax_scare/ |title=Calif. man convicted in nationwide anthrax scare |date=17 September 2009 |work=Salon |accessdate=10 December 2009 }}{{dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> and sentenced to four years in prison in late April 2010.<ref>[http://gsn.nti.org/gsn/nw_20100427_9709.php gsn.nti.org]</ref>
In November 2008, white powder was mailed to temples of [[The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints]] (Mormons) in [[Los Angeles California Temple|Los Angeles]] and [[Salt Lake Temple|Salt Lake City]], causing both to be closed temporarily while the mailings were investigated. There was speculation the mailings were in protest of the support by the Church for [[Proposition 8]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/27707413/ns/us_news-crime_and_courts/t/white-powder-sent-mormon-temples/|title=White powder sent to Mormon temples|work=Associated Press|date=13 November 2008|accessdate=14 October 2011}}</ref>
Notable recipients of anthrax hoax letters include journalist [[Judith Miller (journalist)|Judith Miller]], author of ''[[Germs: Biological Weapons and America's Secret War]]'', who received one at the ''New York Times'' offices in October 2001.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2001/10/15/opinion/in-america-living-with-fear.html|title=In America; Living With Fear|last=Herbert|first=Bob|date=15 October 2001|work=New York Times|accessdate=10 December 2009}}</ref>

This is a chronicle of important events that took place under the [[Shunzhi Emperor]] of the [[Qing Dynasty]] (1636–1912) in what is now [[China]]. It spans from the death of his predecessor [[Hong Taiji]] (r. 1626–1643) in September 1643, to the emperor's own death on 5 February 1661, seven days into the eighteenth year of the Shunzhi [[Chinese era name|reign period]]. These dates do not correspond perfectly with the Shunzhi era itself, which started on 8 February 1644—on [[Chinese New Year|New Year's Day]] of the [[lunisolar calendar|lunisolar year]] following the emperor's accession—and ended on 17 February 1662 (the last day of the 18th year of Shunzhi), more than one [[solar year]] after the emperor's death. The posthumous events related to the Shunzhi Emperor's burial and posthumous cult are also included.
==Dorgon regency== <!--please do not add anything to this timeline without citing a reliable source (see [[WP:RS]] and [[WP:V]])--thanks-->
===1643=== *'''September 21''': [[Hong Taiji]] dies after a successful seventeen-year reign during which the [[Qing]] became a major power in northeast Asia.<ref>{{harvnb|Oxnam|1975}} (p. 38), {{harvnb|Wakeman|1985}} (p. 297), and {{harvnb|Gong|2010}} (p. 51) all place Hong Taiji's death on September 21 (Chongde 崇德 8.8.9). {{harvnb|Dennerline|2002}} (p. 74) gives the date as September 9.</ref> His death threatens to split the Manchus just as they are preparing to attack the Ming.<ref>{{harvnb|Dennerline|2002|p=74}}.</ref> *'''September 26''': a [[Deliberative Council]] of princes and high officials is convened and decides that five-year-old Fulin, [[Hong Taiji]]'s ninth son, will succeed his father, but that Hong Taiji's half-brother [[Dorgon]] and [[Jirgalang]] will be his co-regents. This deal is a compromise between those who wanted to keep the throne in Hung Taiji's descent (the main candidate was Hong Taiji's eldest son [[Hooge (prince)|Hooge]]) and those who supported Dorgon. *'''October 8''': at the age of six ''sui'', [[Fulin]] officially becomes [[Emperor of China|Emperor]] of the Qing dynasty.<ref>{{harvnb|Fang|1943|p=255}}.</ref>
===1644=== *'''February 8''': in [[Xi'an]], [[Li Zicheng]] founds the "[[Shun Dynasty|Great Shun]]" dynasty and proclaims himself King. *'''February 17''': [[Jirgalang]] willingly yields control of all official matters to his co-regent [[Dorgon]].<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|p=299}}.</ref> *'''March 5''': Dorgon sends an amicable letter to Li Zicheng proposing that they "devise a plan in common to unite their forces" against the Ming.<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|pages=304}}.</ref> *'''March 17''': the Shun army occupies [[Taiyuan]] in [[Shanxi]]. *'''April 5''': Seeing the progress of rebel armies in north China, the Chongzhen Emperor issues a call for the immediate help of any military commandant in the empire.<ref>{{harvnb|Struve|1988|p=641}}.</ref> *'''April 24''': Li Zicheng enters [[Beijing]], the capital of the [[Ming dynasty|Ming empire]]. *'''April 25''': the [[Chongzhen Emperor]] commits suicide on a hill behind the [[Forbidden City]]. *'''April 26''': [[Wu Sangui]], a powerful Ming general, moves his army through [[Shanhai Pass]] (at the eastern end of the [[Great Wall]]) and marches toward Beijing in response to the emperor's distress call. When he hears that the capital has fallen, Wu returns to fortify Shanhai Pass.<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|p=290}}.</ref> Wu's departure from the fortified city of [[Xingcheng|Ningyuan]], where [[Battle of Ningyuan|Ming armies had defeated]] Qing founder [[Nurhaci]] in 1626, leaves all territory outside the Great Wall under Qing control. *'''April 29''': the victorious Li Zicheng holds an audience with several thousand Ming officials outside the Donghua Gate of the Forbidden City. Assisted by his main [[Grand Secretary]] [[Niu Jinxing]] (牛金星), Li selected 92 officials to serve in the Shun government. The remaining literati are given over to Shun generals for punishment.<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|pages=277–79}}.</ref> *'''May 5''': Wu Sangui routs an army led by Tang Tong, which Li Zicheng had despatched to attack Shanhai Pass.<ref name="Wakeman 296">{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|page=296}}.</ref> *'''May 10''': Tang Tong's defeated army returns toward Shanhai Pass with reinforcements, but is again defeated by Wu Sangui. Wu takes the city of Yongping (永平) on the road to Beijing.<ref name="Wakeman 296"/> *'''May 13''': words reach the Qing capital of Shengjing that Li Zicheng has been brutalizing former Ming officials and the population of Beijing. Grand Secretary Fan Wencheng uses these news to argue for a Qing intervention in China.<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|page=304}}.</ref> Dorgon agrees to mount a military expedition to punish the rebels and occupy the Central Plains of China.<ref name="Wakeman 305">{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|p=305}}.</ref> *'''May 14''': Dorgon leads the Qing "Grand Army" out of Shengjing and starts marching south toward the Great Wall.<ref name="Wakeman 305"/> *'''May 18''': After the defeat of two of his armies a few days earlier, Li Zicheng decides to take Shanhai Pass himself: he leaves Beijing with an army of 60,000 troops.<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|page=296}}, note 212.</ref> *'''May 20''': two of Wu Sangui's lieutenants arrive at Dorgon's camp at the [[Liao River]] carrying a message from their master asking the Manchus to help Wu defeat Li Zicheng's bandits and restore the Ming dynasty in return for "great profits" (大利).<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|page=297}} (date of arrival at the Manchus' camp) and 300–1 (content of the letter).</ref> Dorgon sends a letter back to Wu Sangui offering.<ref name="Wakeman 305"/> Later that day the Manchus hear for the first time that the Chongzhen emperor was dead.<ref name="Wakeman 305"/> Still on that day, but as a result of earlier plans, small groups of Qing troops start to cross the Great Wall to distribute written proclamations announcing that the Qing army will not harm the population and will only kill Li Zicheng's bandits.<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|pages=306–307}}.</ref> *'''May 25''': By that date, Li Zicheng's army was already camping in the outskirts of Shanhai Pass, near the Sha River a few kilometers west of the Shanhai Pass garrison; Wu Sangui sends his troops to confront him there.<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|page=309}}.</ref> Dorgon receives a letter confirming that Wu Sangui has accepted to work for the Qing: he takes his army on a forced march toward Shanhai Pass.<ref name="Wakeman 310">{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|page=310}}.</ref> *'''May 26''': having covered more than 150 kilometers in 24 hours, Dorgon's troops settle eight kilometers away from the Pass to rest for a few hours. They are awoken at midnight to continue marching.<ref name="Wakeman 310"/> *'''May 27''': [[Battle of Shanhai Pass]]. At dawn Dorgon's main army reaches the gates of Shanhaiguan, where Dorgon receives Wu Sangui's formal surrender.<ref name="Wakeman 310"/> The armies deploy for battle: placed in the vanguard, Wu's troops are ordered to charge the Shun army, but they are unable to break the rebels' line and suffer heavy casualties. By the late afternoon, they are on the verge of defeat when a sandstorm starts blowing on the battlefield.<ref name="Wakeman 311">{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|page=311}}.</ref> Dorgon chooses this moment to intervene: galloping around Wu's right flank, Qing bannermen destroys Li's left wing.<ref name="Wakeman 311"/> The Shun army is defeated and retreats chaotically toward Yongping; thousands are massacred.<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|page=311–12}}.</ref> *'''May 28''': Li Zicheng retreats from Yongping toward Beijing.<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|page=312}}.</ref> Wu Sangui is named Prince Pingxi; his remaining troops shave their heads and join the Qing forces.<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|page=312}}, note 262.</ref> *'''May 31''': Li Zicheng reenters Beijing with his troops, which started to loot the capital.<ref name="Wakeman 313">{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|page=313}}.</ref> *'''June 3''': as a "final gesture of defiance" after his decisive defeat at Shanhai Pass, Li Zicheng officially declares himself [[Emperor of China|Emperor]] of the Great Shun at the Wuying dian 武英殿.<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|page=313}} (citation and date); {{harvnb|Gong|2010|p=74}} (Wuying dian).</ref> *'''June 4''': after 42 days in Beijing, Li Zicheng sets the imperial palaces on fire and abandons the capital to flee toward the west.<ref name="Wakeman 313"/> The Beijing population massacres rebels who had not fled; nearly two thousand are killed.<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|page=313–14}}.</ref> *'''June 5''': led by Dorgon, Qing troops are welcomed into the capital; the Beijing population is shocked because it was expecting Wu Sangui to bring back the Ming heir apparent.<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|pages=314–15}}.</ref> *'''June 7''': Dorgon issues special proclamations to officials around the capital, assuring them that if the local population accepts to cut their hair and to surrender, the officials will be allowed to stay at their post.<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|p=416}}.</ref> (See June 25.) *'''June 25''': because peasant rebellions quickly erupted around the capital in reaction to the haircutting order of June 7, Dorgon issues an edict saying that people will be allowed to arrange their hair the way they want.<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985}}, pp. 420–422. {{harvnb|Gong|2010|p=84}} gives the date as June 28.</ref> *'''July 14''': Dorgon declares Beijing (which he calls "Yanjing" 燕京) the new capital of the Qing.<ref>{{harvnb|Naquin|2000|p=289}} (gives the date as Shunzhi 1.6.11).</ref> [[Mukden]] (present-day Shenyang), which had been the Qing capital since 1634, is retained as a secondary capital.<ref>{{harvnb|Rawski|1998|p=19}}.</ref> *'''July 29''': at the request of his superior, German [[Jesuit]] missionary [[Johann Adam Schall von Bell]] petitions the Qing throne, claiming that the Jesuit calendar is more accurate than the other ones available.<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|p=857}}, note 24.</ref> *'''October 19''': the six-year-old Emperor arrives in Beijing through the Zhengyang Gate, where he is welcomed by Dorgon.<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|p=857}}.</ref> *'''October 31''': the Jesuit Johann Adam Schall von Bell is made Director of the Bureau of Astronomy (欽天監) after a test of the Jesuits' prediction for an eclipse on September 1 proved to be more accurate than those of the court's official astronomer.<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985}}, pp. 857–58, note 24.</ref> *'''November 8''': a formal ritual of imperial enthronement is held for Fulin, during which the merits of Dorgon as regent are compared to those of the [[Duke of Zhou]].<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985}}, pp. 858 and 860.</ref> Dorgon's title is raised from "Prince Regent" to "Uncle Prince Regent" (Shufu shezheng wang 叔父攝政王), in which ''shufu'' (''ecike'' in Manchu) represents a rank higher than that of imperial prince.<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985}}, pp. 860–61, and p. 861, note 31.</ref> *'''November 11''': Hooge is reinstated to the status of [[Prince Su]]; Dorgon's brother Ajige is named Prince Ying; Jirgalang is demoted from "Prince Regent" to "Assistant Uncle Prince Regent" (Fu zheng shuwang 輔政叔王).<ref name="Wakeman 1985 861">{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|p=861}}.</ref>
===1645=== *'''January 20''': the court orders that land without owners be reclaimed and given to Bannermen (圈地). In fact even land that has owners and occupants is confiscated.<ref>{{harvnb|Gong|2010|pp=109–10}}.</ref> (Say more.) *'''June 16''': it is declared that all official documents will heretofore refer to Dorgon as "Imperial Uncle Prince Regent" (''Huang shufu shezheng wang'' 皇叔父攝政王).<ref name="Wakeman 1985 861"/> Court ceremonies are also reformed to elevate Dorgon's ritual position even higher.<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|p=862}}.</ref> *'''June 17''': the Prince of Fu, who had been reigning as the "Hongguang Emperor" since June of the previous year, is captured near Nanjing by Qing forces led by [[Liu Liangzuo]].<ref>{{harvnb|Struve|1988|p=666}}.</ref> *'''July 8''': all people who submit to the Qing dynasty are ordered to shave their forehead and tie their hair into a queue.<ref>{{harvnb|Gong|2010|p=128}}.</ref> This "haircutting command" provokes widespread resistance among the Chinese population. *'''July 29''': [[Zhu Yujian]], the Prince of Tang, is named Regent (or "Protector of the State" 監國).<ref name="Struve 1988 665">{{harvnb|Struve|1988|p=665}}.</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Gong|2010|p=131}}.</ref> *'''August 18''': [[Zhu Yujian]], the Prince of Tang, is proclaimed [[Emperor of China|emperor]] less than a month after arriving in Fuzhou.<ref name="Struve 1988 665"/><ref>{{harvnb|Gong|2010|p=140}}.</ref> He will reign under the title of Longwu 隆武. *'''August 24''': fall of [[Jiading District|Jiading]] to the forces of [[Li Chengdong]], a former Ming general who was now serving the Qing; he orders a massacre of the entire population.<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985}}, pp. 658–59.</ref> *'''September 22''': Li Chengdong takes Songjiang.<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|page=672}}.</ref> *'''October 9''': the city of [[Jiangyin]] falls to Qing armies led by [[Liu Liangzuo]] after a siege of 83 days. The entire population (about 100,000 victims) is massacred over the next two days.<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1975|page=83}}.</ref>
===1646=== *'''September 29 and 30''': hearing that Qing troops were approaching, the court of the [[Zhu Yujian, Prince of Tang|Longwu Emperor]] leaves Yanping in western Fujian and tries to flee toward Ganzhou in Jiangxi.<ref name="Struve 676">{{harvnb|Struve|1988|p=676}}.</ref> *'''October 6''': a Qing contingent catches up with the fleeing Longwu Emperor and executes him summarily.<ref name="Struve 676"/> *'''October 17''' or '''27''': the Qing army captures Fuzhou unopposed.<ref>{{harvnb|Struve|1988}} (p. 676) gives October 17; {{harvnb|Gong|2010}} (p. 171) has October 27 (Shunzhi 3.9.19).</ref> *'''November 19''': the Qing forbids officials to memorialize about five controversial issues: haircutting (剃髮), costume (衣冠), the seizure of lands (圈地), (投充), and runaway slaves (逃人).<ref name="Gong 2010 173">{{harvnb|Gong|2010|p=173}}.</ref> *'''November 20''': [[Zhu Youlang]], the Ming Prince of Gui, is named protector of the state (監國) in [[Zhaoqing]] (Guangdong); it is decided that he will reign under the title Yongli 永曆.<ref name="Gong 2010 173"/> *'''December 21''': [[Zheng Zhilong]], who had defended the [[Longwu]] court, surrenders to the Qing in Fuzhou. He is taken north as a prisoner.<ref>{{harvnb|Gong|2010|p=176}}.</ref>
===1647=== *'''February 1''': Bandit leader [[Zhang Xianzhong]] is killed in battle by Qing troops led by [[Hooge (prince)|Hooge]], the son of Hong Taiji who had failed to succeed his father on the imperial throne in 1643.<ref>{{harvnb|Dai|2009}}, pp. 17–18.</ref> *'''August 2''': Dorgon's brother Dodo is named [[Dodo, Prince Yu|Prince Yu]].<ref name="Gong 2010 192">{{harvnb|Gong|2010|p=192}}.</ref> *'''September 7''': The Qing court forbids Portuguese merchants based in [[Macao]] from entering the provinces to trade.<ref name="Gong 2010 192"/> *'''September 28 / October 27''' (SZ4.9): the court receives an embassy sent by the Ryukyu king to congratulate the Shunzhi Emperor on his accession.<ref>{{harvnb|Gong|2010|p=194}}.</ref>
===1648=== *'''February 25''': Haoge (Prince Su) returns to the capital after his victorious but costly Sichuan campaign (see Feb. 1, 1647).<ref>{{harvnb|Gong|2010|p=198}}.</ref> *'''March 29''': Dorgon demotes [[Jirgalang]] from Prince Zheng to Prince of the second rank (郡王).<ref name="Gong 2010 199">{{harvnb|Gong|2010|p=199}}.</ref> He was given back his rank on '''May 25'''.<ref>{{harvnb|Gong|2010|p=202}}.</ref> *'''April 5''': [[Names of Vietnam|Annam]] sends a tributary embassy to the [[Southern Ming]].<ref name="Gong 2010 199"/> *'''March 24 / April 22''' (SZ5.3): Milayin and Ding Guodong rise against the Qing in Gansu.<ref>{{harvnb|Gong|2010|p=200}}.</ref>
===1649=== *'''April 29''': [[Dodo, Prince Yu|prince Dodo]] (Dorgon's brother from the same mother) dies of [[smallpox]] in Beijing.<ref name="Dennerline 99">{{harvnb|Dennerline|2002|page=99}}.</ref> Dorgon's other [[uterine brother]] Ajige is placed in charge of managing the affairs of the capital.<ref name="Dennerline 99"/> *'''May 27''': [[Empress Xiaoduanwen|Empress Dowager Xiaoduanwen]], [[Hong Taiji]]'s former empress, dies.<ref>''Qingshi gao'' ("[[Draft History of Qing]]"), ch. 214 ("Biographies of consorts" 后妃傳), p. 8901, where the exact date of death is recorded as the ''yisi'' 乙巳 day of the 4th month of the 6th year of Shunzhi.</ref> As a result, the Shunzhi emperor's mother [[Empress Dowager Xiaozhuang]] becomes the most powerful woman in the palace.<ref>{{harvnb|Rawski|1998|p=135}}.</ref> *'''October 4''': Qing banner troops take back [[Datong]] (Shanxi) from the hands of rebellious commander Jiang Xiang.<ref>{{harvnb|Dennerline|2002|p=100}}.</ref> *'''December 30''': [[Geng Zhongming]] (耿仲明; 1604–1649) commits suicide in Jiangxi after being accused of protecting subordinates who had helped three hundred runaway slaves to hide from their masters.<ref name="Wakeman 1985 1017">{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|p=1017}}.</ref> His armies, now led by his son [[Geng Jimao]] (耿繼茂), nonetheless continue to fight the [[Southern Ming]].<ref name="Wakeman 1985 1017"/>
===1650=== *'''November 24''': After a long siege, Qing armies led by [[Shang Kexi]] capture [[Guangzhou|Canton]] and massacre its population.<ref name="Dennerline 101">{{harvnb|Dennerline|2002|page=101}}.</ref> Firmly entrenched in the south, Shang later became one of the [[Three Feudatories]]. *'''November 26''': [[Kong Youde]] 孔有德 (1602–1652) captures [[Guilin]] ([[Guangxi]]) for the Qing.<ref name="Dennerline 101"/> *'''December 31''': Dorgon dies at the age of 38 during a hunting expedition.<ref name="Dennerline 101"/> His death created an immediate backlash against his political allies at court.
==Transition and personal rule== <!--please do not add anything to this timeline without citing a reliable source (see [[WP:CITE]] and [[WP:V]])--thanks-->
===1651=== *'''January 26''': Dorgon's brother [[Ajige]] is imprisoned for allegedly plotting a coup after the death of Dorgon.<ref>{{harvnb|Dennerline|2002}}, pp. 101–102.</ref> He was forced to commit suicide later that year.<ref>{{harvnb|Dennerline|2002|page=104}}.</ref> *'''April 7''': the Shunzhi Emperor issues an edict declaring his intention to root out corruption among officials.<ref>{{harvnb|Dennerline|2002|page=106}}.</ref> The anticorruption campaign that followed first targeted officials who had been close to Dorgon, but it soon led to a revival of factional politics among literati officials, a problem that plagued the young emperor until his death in 1661.<ref>{{harvnb|Dennerline|2002}}, pp. 106–107.</ref> *'''September''': the emperor marries a niece of his mother the Empress Dowager.<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|p=929}}.</ref> *'''October 31''': the monumental "Gate of Receiving Heaven" (Chengtian men 承天門) facing south from the imperial city is renamed "Gate of Heavenly Peace" ([[Tiananmen]] 天安門).<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|p=928}}.</ref> *'''December 13''': Consort Ba 巴 gives birth to Niuniu 牛鈕, the Shunzhi emperor's first son.<ref>''Qingshi gao'', ch. 5, p. 127, Shunzhi 8.11.乙亥 (1st). The mother is named in ''Qingshi gao'', ch. 219, p. 9052.</ref>
===1652=== *'''March 9''': death of the emperor's first son Niuniu less than three months after his birth.<ref>''Qingshi gao'', ch. 5, p. 128, Shunzhi 9.1.壬寅 (30th).</ref> *'''Spring''': in an edict to the [[Inner Three Courts]], the Shunzhi Emperor orders that all memorials concerning state matters should now be sent to him rather than to Jirgalang's office.<ref name="Lui 46">{{harvnb|Lui|1989|p=46}}.</ref> This marks the time when the monarch takes full charge of the government.<ref name="Lui 46"/> *'''August 7''': Southern Ming loyalist [[Li Dingguo]], an ancient lieutenant of bandit king [[Zhang Xianzhong]], retakes the key southwestern city of [[Guilin]] from the Qing; the Qing commander-in-chief Kong Youde commits suicide.<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985}}, pp. 972 (Kong commits suicide) and 973, note 194 (taking of Guilin by Li).</ref> Within a month, most of the [[Guangxi]] military commanders who had served the Qing reverted to the Ming side.<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|p=973}}, note 194.</ref>
===1653=== *'''January 14''': the [[Fifth Dalai Lama]] arrives in Beijing to meet with the Shunzhi Emperor.<ref>{{harvnb|Li|2003|p=476}}; {{harvnb|Gong|2010|p=258}} (the former cites the entry from the Qing ''Veritable Records'' indicating the date of the Dalai Lama's arrival).</ref> He leaves about two months later.<ref>{{harvnb|Li|2003|p=476}}.</ref> *'''April 25''': the emperor recalls [[Feng Quan]] 馮銓 to serve in the government again.<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|p=954}}.</ref> That very evening he was summoned to meet with the emperor, [[Hong Chengchou]], and [[Chen Mingxia]] 陳名夏<ref>{{cite journal |last=Godley |first=Michael R. |last2= |first2= |date= |title=The End of the Queue: Hair as Symbol in Chinese History |url=http://www.chinaheritagequarterly.org/features.php?searchterm=027_queue.inc&issue=027 |journal=China Heritage Quarterly |publisher=The Australian National University |volume= |issue= |pages= |doi= |access-date=23 August 2016}}</ref> to discuss the qualifications of [[Hanlin Academy]] compilers, who had been mostly appointed by Chen Mingxia, a southerner.<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|p=956}}.</ref> Even though Shunzhi was trying to counteract the influence of southern Chinese officials who advocated a return to Ming government practices, by recalling a pro-Manchu collaborator like Feng Quan, he actually intensified the tensions between northern and southern Chinese literati.<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|p=958}}.</ref> *'''July 23''': to counteract the power of the [[Imperial Household Department]], Shunzhi establishes the Thirteen Offices (内十三衙门), which are controlled by eunuchs.<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|p=931}}. The exact date can be found in {{harvnb|Gong|2010|p=266}}.</ref> These bureaus allowed eunuch power to grow;<ref>{{harvnb|Fang|1943|p=257}}.</ref> they were eliminated by Oboi and the other regents at the beginning of the Kangxi reign. *'''September 8''': Consort Ningyi 寧懿 of the [[Donggo]] clan gives birth to [[Fuquan (prince)|Fuquan]], the emperor's second son.<ref>''Qingshi gao'', ch. 5, p. 135, Shunzhi 10.7.庚戌 (17th).</ref> He died in 1703.<ref>''Qingshi gao'', ch. 8, p. 263, Kangxi 42.6.壬寅 (28th), or August 10, 1703.</ref> *'''December 15''': The court forbids actors (優人) from not shaving their hair on the pretext that they have to play female roles.<ref>{{harvnb|Gong|2010|p=267}}.</ref>
===1654=== *'''March 8''': [[Shang Kexi]] is appointed to govern 鎮 [[Guangdong]], whereas [[Geng Jimao]] is ordered to garrison [[Guilin]] and to take care of the Green Standard Armies that had been established by [[Kong Youde]].<ref>{{harvnb|Gong|2010|p=269}}.</ref> *'''April 27''': on recommendation by the [[Deliberative Council of Princes and Ministers]] led by [[Jirgalang]], [[Chen Mingxia]] (陳名夏), who had been an influential [[Grand Secretary]], is executed by strangling after a ten-day trial for corruption that started when he proposed to restore the hairstyle and court costume of the Ming dynasty.<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|pages=985–86}}.</ref> *'''May 4''': [[Xiao Hui Zhang|Empress Xiaohui]] gives birth to the emperor third son [[Xuanye]] 玄燁 ([[Manchu language|Manchu]]: {{MongolUnicode|ᡥᡳᠣᠸᠠᠨ ᠶᡝᡳ}} Hiowan Yei), who later became the [[Kangxi Emperor]].
===1655=== *'''March 14''': Jirgalang asks the Emperor to establish an Imperial Diarist 起居注官 to keep a diary of the emperor's movements.<ref>{{harvnb|Gong|2010|p=270}}.</ref>
===1656=== *'''August 6''': The Qing forbids sea trade in the southeastern provinces. Private merchant ships are forbidden from trading and other ships from accosting.<ref name="Gong 2010 288">{{harvnb|Gong|2010|p=288}}.</ref> The purpose of this policy was to eliminate those among sea merchants who supported the Southern Ming power of [[Zheng Chenggong]].<ref name="Gong 2010 288"/>
===1657=== *'''November 5''': [[Empress Xiao Xian|Imperial Noble Consort Donggo]], the emperor's favorite consort, gives birth to the emperor's fourth son, who died before he was given a name (see February 25, 1658). *'''November 30''': the Shuntian examination cheating scandal erupts.<ref>{{harvnb|Gong|2010|p=295}}.</ref> *'''December 8''': the emperor's fifth son, [[Changning (prince)|Changning]], is born to Consort Chen 陳.<ref>''Qingshi gao'', ch. 5, p. 150, Shunzhi 14.11.壬寅 (4th). The mother is named in ''Qingshigao'', ch. 219, p. 9052.</ref> He became Prince Gong (恭親王) in 1671 and died in 1703.<ref>Date of his becoming prince: ''Qingshi gao'', ch. 6, p. 180, Kangxi 10.1.癸酉 (21st), i.e., 1 March 1671. Date of death: ''Qingshi gao'', ch. 8, p. 263, Kangxi 42.6.辛巳 (7th), i.e., 20 July 1703.</ref>
===1658=== *'''February 25''': death of the emperor's fourth son a little more than 100 days after his birth. He was posthumously granted the title of Prince Rong (榮親王).<ref>{{Harvnb|Li|2003|pp=594–95}}.</ref> *'''August 13''': the emperor changes the old Manchu Inner Three Courts into a "Palace Secretariat" (''diange'' 殿閣) and reinstitutes the old [[Hanlin Academy]], both based on old Ming institutions.<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|p=1007}}.</ref> Though these institutions were abrogated during the [[Oboi regency]] (1661–1669), the [[Kangxi Emperor]] reinstated them in 1670 (the former as the "Grand Secretariat," or ''neige'' 內閣) and they lasted until the end of the Qing in 1911.
===1659=== *'''January 25''': Qing forces led by prince Dodo's second son Doni enter the capital of Yunnan, sending the [[Yongli Emperor]] into flight to Burma under the protection of [[Li Dingguo]].<ref>{{harvnb|Dennerline|2002|page=117}}. {{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|p=1034}} gives the date as January 23.</ref> *'''March 7''': the core of the Southern Ming army is defeated at [[Dali City|Dali]], forcing the [[Yongli Emperor]], the last monarch of the southern Ming, to flee toward [[Burma]].<ref>{{harvnb|Wakeman|1985|p=1034}}.</ref>
===1660=== *'''January 3''': birth of the emperor's sixth son Qishou 奇授 (Manchu: Kišeo) to Consort Tang 唐.<ref>''Qingshi gao'', ch. 5, p. 156, Shunzhi 16.11.戊寅 (21st). The mother is identified in ''Qingshi gao'', ch. 219, p. 9052.</ref> He died at an unspecified date at the age of seven [[East Asian age reckoning|''sui'']].<ref name="Qingshi gao, ch. 214, p. 8910">''Qingshi gao'', ch. 214, p. 8910.</ref> *'''March 6''': to counter factional politics, the Shunzhi emperor issues an edict banning clubs or societies whose purpose was to influence government affairs or public opinion.<ref>{{harvnb|Struve|1982|p=258}}.</ref> *'''May 30''': Consort Niu gives birth to the emperor's seventh son, Longxi 隆禧 (Manchu: Lunghi).<ref>''Qingshi gao'', ch. 5, pp. 158–59, Shunzhi 17.4.丙午 (22nd).</ref> He died in 1679.<ref>''Qingshi gao'', ch. 6, p. 200, Kangxi 18.7.丁未 (15th), or August 20, 1679.</ref> *'''September 23''': death of the emperor's favorite concubine, "Imperial Consort of the Second Rank" Donggo.<ref>{{harvnb|Standaert|2008|p=72}}.</ref> Jesuit missionary [[Adam Schall]], who had been close to the emperor in 1656 and 1657 and who attended the concubine's expensive funerals, later claimed that "Through her death she made [the emperor] fall into a madness more repulsive than the one of [[Solomon|Salomon]], because he openly displayed himself as a disciple of [[Sangha (Buddhism)|the Bonzes]], shaving his head, and living and dressing himself like them."<ref>{{harvnb|Standaert|2008}} pp. 72 (in the words of Schall, "a very great Funeral" with many "wasteful ceremonies") and 74 (citation).</ref>
===1661=== *'''January 23''': birth of the emperor's eighth son, Yonggan, to Consort Muktu 穆克圖.<ref>''Qingshi gao'', ch. 5, p. 161, Shunzhi 17.12.甲辰 (23rd). The mother is mentioned in ''Qingshi gao'', ch. 219, p. 9052.</ref> He died at an unspecified date at the age of eight [[East Asian age reckoning|''sui'']].<ref name="Qingshi gao, ch. 214, p. 8910"/> *'''February 5''': the Shunzhi emperor dies of [[smallpox]].<ref>{{harvnb|Dennerline|2002|page=118}}.</ref>
==After death== <!--please do not add anything to this timeline without citing a reliable source (see [[WP:RS]] and [[WP:V]])--thanks-->
===1661=== *'''March 2''': in a lavish procession, the emperor's body is transported to Jingshan—north of the Forbidden City—where it stayed for about two years until the emperor was finally buried.<ref>{{harvnb|Standaert|2008|pp=74–75}}.</ref> On '''March 3''' a large number of precious goods are burned as offerings, after which the [[Kangxi Emperor|new emperor]] takes off his mourning dress.<ref>{{harvnb|Standaert|2008|pp=73–74}}.</ref> *'''April 22''': the dead emperor is given a [[temple name]] (Shizu 世祖)—by which he would be worshipped at the [[Imperial Ancestral Temple]]—and an honorific [[posthumous name]] (體天隆運定統建極英睿欽文顯武大德弘功至仁純孝章皇帝 ''Titian longyun dingtong jianji yingrui qinwen xianwu dade honggong zhiren chunxiao zhang huangdi'').<ref>''Qingshi gao'' ["[[Draft History of Qing]]"], ch. 5, p. 163: Shunzhi 18.3.癸酉 (24th day of that month).</ref>
===1662=== *'''January 13''': the ancestral tablets of the Shunzhi emperor are placed at the [[Imperial Ancestral Temple]], where he will be worshipped under the [[temple name]] Shizu.<ref>''Qingshi gao'' ["[[Draft History of Qing]]"], chapter 6, p. 167. Date: Shunzhi 18.11.己亥 (24th day of that month).</ref>
===1663=== *'''July 5 / August 2''' (KX2.6): the emperor's body is buried at the Xiaoling.<ref>''Qingshi gao'' ["[[Draft History of Qing]]"], chapter 6, p. 169.</ref>

{{short description|The history and future of the universe according to Big Bang cosmology}} {{see also|Timeline of the formation of the Universe}} {{pp-move-indef|small=yes}} [[File:CMB Timeline300 no WMAP.jpg|thumb|upright=2|Diagram of evolution of the (observable part) of the universe from the Big Bang (left) to the present]] {{Physical cosmology}} {{Nature timeline}} The '''chronology of the universe''' describes the history and [[future of the universe]] according to [[Big Bang]] cosmology. The earliest stages of the universe's existence are estimated as taking place 13.8 [[billion years]] ago, with an [[confidence level|uncertainty]] of around 21 million years at the 68% confidence level. The [[Planck (spacecraft)#2015 data release|Planck Collaboration]] in 2015 published the estimate of 13.799 ± 0.021 billion years ago (68% confidence interval). See Table 4 on page 31 of pdf. {{Cite journal |author=Planck Collaboration |date=2015 |title=Planck 2015 results. XIII. Cosmological parameters |journal=[[Astronomy & Astrophysics]] |volume=594 |issue=13 |pages=A13 |arxiv=1502.01589 |doi=10.1051/0004-6361/201525830 |bibcode=2016A&A...594A..13P }} ==Outline== For the purposes of this summary, it is convenient to divide the chronology of the universe since it [[Cosmogony|originated]], into five parts. It is generally considered meaningless or unclear whether [[time]] existed before this chronology: :'''1. The [[#Very early universe|very early universe]]''' – the first [[picosecond]] (10−12) of cosmic time. It includes the [[Planck epoch]], during which currently understood [[laws of physics]] may not apply; the emergence in stages of the four known [[fundamental interaction]]s or [[force]]s – first [[gravity]], and later the [[strong interaction|strong]], [[weak interaction|weak]] and [[electromagnetic interaction|electromagnetic]] interactions; and the [[metric expansion of space|expansion of space]] and [[supercooling]] of the still immensely hot universe due to [[cosmic inflation]], which is believed to have been triggered by the separation of the [[Strong interaction|strong]] and [[electroweak interaction]]. :Tiny ripples in the universe at this stage are believed to be the basis of large-scale structures that formed much later. Different stages of the very early universe are understood to different extents. The earlier parts are beyond the grasp of practical experiments in [[particle physics]] but can be explored through other means. :'''2. The [[#Early universe|early universe]]''', lasting around 377,000 years. Initially, various kinds of [[subatomic particle]]s are formed in stages. These particles include almost equal amounts of [[matter]] and [[antimatter]], so most of it quickly annihilates, leaving a small excess of matter in the universe. :At about one second, [[Neutrino decoupling|neutrinos decouple]]; these neutrinos form the [[cosmic neutrino background]]. If [[primordial black hole]]s exist, they are also formed at about one second of cosmic time. [[Composite particle|Composite]] [[subatomic particle]]s emerge – including [[proton]]s and [[neutron]]s – and from about 3 minutes, conditions are suitable for [[nucleosynthesis]]: around 25% of the protons and all the neutrons [[nuclear fusion|fuse]] [[big bang nucleosynthesis|into heavier elements]], mainly [[helium-4]]. :By 20 minutes, the universe is no longer hot enough for fusion, but far too hot for neutral [[atom]]s to exist or [[photon]]s to travel far. It is therefore an [[Opacity (optics)|opaque]] [[Plasma (physics)|plasma]]. At around 47,000 years,Ryden, Barbara, "Introduction to Cosmology", 2006, eqn. 6.33, 6.41 as the universe cools, its behavior begins to be dominated by [[matter]] rather than radiation. :At about 377,000 years {{citation needed|date=November 2018}}, the universe finally becomes cool enough for neutral [[atom]]s to form ("[[Recombination (cosmology)|recombination]]"), and as a result it also became [[Transparency and translucency|transparent]] for the first time. The newly formed atoms – mainly [[hydrogen]] and [[helium]] with traces of [[lithium]] – quickly reach their lowest energy state ([[ground state]]) by releasing photons ("[[decoupling (cosmology)|photon decoupling]]"), and these photons can still be detected today as the [[cosmic microwave background]] (CMB). This is currently the oldest observation we have of the universe. :'''3. Dark Ages and large-scale [[structure formation|structure emergence]]''', from 377,000 years until about 1 billion years. After [[recombination (cosmology)|recombination]] and [[decoupling (cosmology)|decoupling]], the universe was transparent but the clouds of [[hydrogen]] only collapsed very slowly to form [[star]]s and [[galaxy|galaxies]], so there were no new sources of light. The only photons (electromagnetic radiation, or "light") in the universe were those released during decoupling (visible today as the [[cosmic microwave background]]) and [[hydrogen line|21 cm radio emissions]] occasionally emitted by hydrogen atoms. The decoupled photons would have filled the universe with a brilliant pale orange glow at first, gradually [[redshift]]ing to non-visible [[wavelength]]s after about 3 million years, leaving it without visible light. This period is known as the [[Dark Ages (cosmology)|Dark Ages]]. :Between about 10 and 17 million years the universe's average temperature was suitable for liquid water (273 – 373K) and there has been speculation whether rocky planets or indeed life could have arisen briefly, since statistically a tiny part of the universe could have had different conditions from the rest, and gained warmth from the universe as a whole. :At some point around 400 to 700 million years, the earliest generations of [[stellar evolution|stars]] and [[galaxy formation and evolution|galaxies form]], and early large structures gradually emerge, drawn to the foam-like [[dark matter]] [[filament (cosmology)|filaments]] which have already begun to draw together throughout the universe. [[Population III star|The earliest generations of stars]] have not yet been observed astronomically. They may have been huge and [[metallicity|non-metallic]] with very short lifetimes compared to [[Main Sequence|most stars we see today]], so they commonly finish burning their [[hydrogen]] fuel and explode as [[supernova]]e after mere millions of years. Other theories suggest that they may have included small stars, some perhaps still burning today. In either case, these early generations of supernovae created most of the everyday [[chemical element|elements]] we see around us today, and seeded the universe with them. :[[Galaxy cluster]]s and [[supercluster]]s emerge over time. At some point, high energy photons from the earliest stars, [[dwarf galaxy|dwarf galaxies]] and perhaps [[quasar]]s led to a period of [[reionization]]. The universe gradually transitioned into the universe we see around us today, and the Dark Ages only fully came to an end at about 1 billion years. :'''4. The universe as it appears today'''. From 1 billion years, and for about 12.8 billions of years, the universe has looked much as it does today. It will continue to appear very similar for many billions of years into the future. The [[thin disk]] of [[Milky Way|our galaxy]] began to form at about 5 billion years (8.8 bn years ago),{{cite journal |last1=del Peloso |first1=E. F. |last2=da Silva |first2=L. |last3=Porto de Mello |first3=G. F. |last4=Arany-Prado |first4=L. I. |title=The age of the Galactic thin disk from Th/Eunucleocosmochronology. III. Extended sample |journal=Astronomy & Astrophysics |date=2005 |volume=440 |issue=3 |pages=1153–1159 |doi=10.1051/0004-6361:20053307 |bibcode= 2005A&A...440.1153D | arxiv=astro-ph/0506458}} and the [[formation and evolution of the Solar System|solar system]] formed at about 9.2 billion years (4.6 bn years ago), with the earliest traces of [[timeline of the evolutionary history of life|life]] on Earth emerging by about 10.3 billion years (3.5 bn years ago). :From about 9.8 billion years of cosmic time, the slowing expansion of space gradually begins to accelerate under the influence of [[dark energy]], which may be a [[scalar field]] throughout our universe. The present-day universe is understood quite well, but beyond about 100 billion years of cosmic time (about 86 billion years in the future), uncertainties in current knowledge mean that we are less sure which path our universe will take. :'''5. [[Fate of the universe|The far future]]'''. At some time the [[Stelliferous Era]] will end as stars are no longer being born, and the expansion of the universe will mean that the observable universe becomes limited to local galaxies. There are various scenarios for the far future and [[ultimate fate of the universe]]. More exact knowledge of our current universe will allow these to be better understood. ==A more detailed summary== {{further|Timeline of the formation of the Universe|Timeline of natural history|Geologic time scale|Timeline of the evolutionary history of life|Timeline of the far future}} {{further|Graphical timeline of the universe|Graphical timeline of the Big Bang|Graphical timeline from Big Bang to Heat Death|Graphical timeline of the Stelliferous Era}} Earliest stages of chronology shown below (before neutrino decoupling) are an active area of research and based on ideas which are still speculative and subject to modification as scientific knowledge improves. "Time" column is based on extrapolation of observed [[metric expansion of space]] back in the past. For the earliest stages of chronology this extrapolation may be invalid. To give one example, [[eternal inflation]] theories propose that inflation lasts forever throughout most of the universe, making the notion of "N seconds since Big Bang" ill-defined. The radiation temperature refers to the [[cosmic background radiation]] and is given by 2.725·(1+''z''), where ''z'' is the [[redshift]]. {| class="wikitable" |---- ! Epoch ! Time !
